title: On the reproducibility of power analyses in motor behavior research
text:
Abstract
Recent metascience suggests that motor behavior research may be underpowered, on average. Researchers can perform a priori power analyses to ensure adequately powered studies. However, there are common pitfalls that can result in underestimating the required sample size for a given design and effect size of interest. Critical evaluation of power analyses requires successful analysis reproduction, which is conditional on the reporting of sufficient information. Here, we attempted to reproduce every power analysis reported in articles (k = 84/635) in three motor behavior journals between January 2019 and June 2021. We reproduced 7% of analyses using the reported information, which increased to 43% when we assumed plausible values for missing parameters. Among studies that reported sufficient information to evaluate, 63% reported using the same statistical test in the power analysis as in the study itself, and in 77%, the test addressed at least one of the identified hypotheses. Overall, power analyses were not commonly reported with sufficient information to ensure reproducibility. A nontrivial number of power analyses were also affected by common pitfalls. There is substantial opportunity to address the issue of underpowered research in motor behavior by increasing adoption of power analyses and ensuring reproducible reporting practices.

title: carterlab
text:
Undergraduate student opportunities
Undergraduate students are vital to the lab’s success and we love working with students from different academic programs and backgrounds. Undergraduate students will have the opportunity to work in the lab as part of their undergraduate degree requirements (e.g., research practicums, honour’s thesis, etc) or to explore an interest in sensorimotor neuroscience by gaining experience as a volunteer research assistant. You will have the opportunity to contribute to all stages of the research process, with the goal of disseminating your findings at an academic conference and/or in a peer-reviewed journal. There is also the possibility of paid summer positions depending on your experience and the availability of funds; however, these positions are generally given to students who have already worked in the lab.
The application period is for practicum, project, or thesis positions in the lab for the 2025-26 academic year is now closed.

General inquiries regarding other undergraduate opportunities in the lab such as NSERC USRA, Kinesiology Summer Research Award, MIRA Summer Research Fellowship, etc can be sent to cartem11 [at] mcmaster [dot] ca.

title: carterlab
text:
Graduate student opportunities
The study of sensorimotor behaviour is multidisciplinary so students with backgrounds in the areas of, but not limited to, kinesiology, neuroscience, psychology, life or health sciences, engineering, or computer science are encouraged to apply. There are a limited number of graduate student positions in the lab at any given time. This approach allows for a more individualized training environment for each student, larger research stipends/bursaries, and the option to attend 1-2 academic conferences each year. Students interested in completing their M.Sc or Ph.D studies in the lab are encouraged to consult the relevant information pertaining to graduate studies in the Department of Kinesiology and the School of Graduate Studies.

M.Sc and Ph.D applicants
If you are interested in completing your M.Sc or Ph.D in the lab, please send 1) an up-to-date curriculum vitae, 2) unofficial academic transcripts, and 3) a 1-page statement of research interests to cartem11 [at] mcmaster [dot] ca.

title: Navishka Brahmbhatt
text: I joined the lab in January of 2024 as an undergraduate practicum student. My research interests include neurodegenerative diseases and rehabilitation sciences. Outside the lab, I enjoy traveling, dancing, and cooking.

My research interests include investigating somatosensory and motor systems, and I also enjoy learning about computer science and organic chemistry on the side. In my spare time I like to rock climb, work out, read (mostly sci-fi and fantasy), and play video games and sports.

title: Aditya Trivedi
text: I joined the lab in January 2024 as a research practicum student. I am currently in my third year of the Honours Life Sciences Program (BSc). My research interests include the acquisition and retention of novel motor skills, as well as individual and collaborative decision-making processes.

title: Jil Soni

Outside of the lab, I enjoy playing badminton and volleyball, baking, and drinking bubble tea.

Outside of the lab, I enjoy playing volleyball, reading fictional novels, and watching true crime and horror shows.
